data.text: Suspension Dropper on the Gravel Bike
Has anyone installed a suspension seat past on their gravel bike? Looking for feedback as I am on my first gravel bike. Just thinking it might be a good addition to the ride. Comments?
I had one. PNW coast suspension dropper. It was alright. I decided I preferred a carbon post and a set position rather than dealing with sag and whatnot.
data.author: KC Merckel

data.text: I have the redshift, pretty happy with it, some of the gravel I ride gets a bit gnarly and I'm getting a tad long in the tooth. I also have the redshift suspension stem.
data.author: Dennis Sneed

data.text: I use the Redshift suspension stem and Thudbuster seatpost. I like my comfort 😬
data.author: Alan Stratford

data.text: Another vote for the Redshift ShockStop suspension seatpost. It's expensive, but worth it. I really notice it when I ride one of my other bikes on gravel that doesn't have the Redshift. It eats up a lot of road chatter.
data.author: Tim Sattler

data.text: I like my tranzx a lot. Probably the best price point and the most minimal looking
data.author: Zach Wagner

data.text: Back to 80's MTB
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: Yep
data.author: Chris Bussiere

data.text: I just keep my ass fattened up.
data.author: Mike Lamarca

data.text: If your bike can handle it, you can't beat a suspension fork
data.author: Vaughan Garner

data.text: I have the eeSilk and it’s perfect. A good bit lighter than the redshift, and just enough travel to take the edge off a long ride. Doesn’t mangle the look of the bike either.
data.author: Eric von Eckartsberg

data.text: just stand up. legs/arms are the smartest suspension we got....
data.author: Lucas Ehster

data.text: Ya, try standing up for 100's of metres in deep, ridged, sand, fully loaded when you're already beat..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: redshift. love it
data.author: Brian Slaughter

data.text: Redshift has been awesome.
data.author: Jeff Bemrose

data.text: I’ve got a Canyon VCLS 2.0 seatpost. Works great
data.author: Max Pasion

data.text: No need unless you're going to be doing some knarly single track. Just adds weight.
data.author: Rusty Nail

data.text: I had the PNW COAST suspension dropper on my Open, that thing was pretty sweet, and it just dawned on me that I can shim that thing out and put it on my Chamois Hagar. I also have the Redshift post on my Cutthroat, you can roll straight down the trail tracks with that sucker! It rides in the upper end of its travel, so you can improve your traction by staying seated through a rough patch. It’s an interesting ride, but o haven’t given it the double century test yet to see if it gets weird on a 20+ hour day. The PNW didn’t sag out the way I had it set up, so it pretty much reduced the impact of sneaker bumps, which is really nice when you’re cracked.
data.author: Justin M Short BA

data.text: YES. MOST UNDERRATED. ANY suspension post improves the ride. Obvi, a $40 one not as good as $100*+ one. *USE Vybe / XCR / SX / RX. My personal faves. Ive had 5 of these (2stolen, 3 tried ended up w XCR). Superlight 380-425g. 1-1.5” travel. Looks normal. Most normal of all. ***Fully Serviceable￼*** 👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼 *Cane Creek eeSilk👍🏼👍🏼👍🏼 , Thudbuster ST or LT 👍🏼👍🏼 *Redshift - 👍🏼 *Kinekt - i thnk most overpriced and least effective, least well designed, not that light and looks wierd.
data.author: Dex Tao

data.text: I have a redshift seat post and suspension stem. Recently did a 46 mile gravel ride on them and they are top notch .Well worth the investment
data.author: Louis Perry

data.text:
I would put a suspension stem on before the seat post, ￼https://youtu.be/jtQ1IEgzYEg
Gravel Bike Suspension - Shockstop Pro by Redshift + Wahoo Mount
youtube.com
data.author: Jeff Waasdorp

data.text: Cane creek Eesilk+ has 35mm
data.author: Josh Flores

data.text: Cane creek eeSilk plus. Love it
data.author: Jason Holzworth

data.text: I’m running an older Thudbuster ST and a Kinekt suspension stem. Adds weight, yes, but much of my local gravel is infrequently maintained, if at all. I prefer a little squish to counter the bumps. I went with the Kinekt stem because I prefer the starlight up and down motion versus the single pivot dive of the Redshift.
data.author: Chris Anthony

data.text: I have the PNW Coast on my Tour Divide hardtail MTB and it was worth every penny plus. I don’t like droppers but the Coast has 40mm of suspension travel and 120mm dropper. If I keep my hardtails and my full rigid gravel bike they will all have the PNW Coast on them before the end of the year.
data.author: James Falke

data.text: Why a gravel bike? What does it matter what kind of bike it is other than 'not a full-suspension' bike.. Sus' seatposts are great for taking the small bumps out - roots, small potholes, any unevenness in the road/trail on any bike that doesn't have a rear shock..
data.author: Adam Macer
